Test-negative case–control studies
4– 9 are based on persons who undergo testing because they present with signs and symptoms of a particular disease. The cases are those who test positive for the disease, and the controls are those who test negative—the latter will have another reason for their signs and symptoms, most likely another disease.
8 These “cases” and “controls” usually come from one geographic population, although not everyone in a particular area may present for testing (and some people may come from outside the area).
